name: Lung function(s)
question1: How would you assess and measure a patient’s lung function?
contents:
Evaluation of a patient’s pulmonary function requires correlation of history, examination findings and relevant investigation results in conjunction with the nature of proposed surgery.


History and examination findings may provide valuable information about a patient’s respiratory function.

Pertinent history should include:

  • history of pre-existing lung disease (e.g. COPD, asthma, pulmonary fibrosis),
  • smoking history (quantified via pack-year history),
  • exercise tolerance,
  • respiratory symptoms (cough, sputum production, wheeze),
  • number and frequency of hospital admissions with respiratory problems, and
  • current treatment regimen (e.g. bronchodilators, steroids, supplemental oxygen).


Risk factors:

  • Patient factors:
  • > Age >70 years
  • > History of lung disease
  • > BMI >30
  • > Smoking history >20-pack year
  • Surgical factors:
  • > Upper abdominal surgery
  • > Thoracic surgery
  • > Open vs. laparoscopic procedures

Investigations:

  • Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR)
  • ABG
  • Spirometery
  • Interpretation of spirometry data
  • Flow volume loops (constructed from spirometric data.)
  • Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET)
  • Cycle ergometry is the most common mode of exercise
  • Non-invasive and objective method of evaluating both cardiac and pulmonary functions
  • Primarily determines if the patient has normal or reduced maximal exercise capacity ( VO2 max). Reduced VO2 max can further suggest probable causes
  • Respiratory muscle strength
  • Carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLco or transfer factor)
  • Conditions that are associated with a reduced DLco
  • > Primary pulmonary hypertension
  • > Pulmonary embolism
  • > Emphysema
  • > Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Conditions that are associated with an increased DLco
  • > Polycythaemia
  • > Alveolar haemorrhage
question2: Describe a normal, obstructive and restrictive flow-volume loops.
contents2:
Flow-volume loops

  • Peak inspiratory flow is less than peak expiratory flow
  • Flow increases then reduces as inspiration progresses
  • Initial expiratory flow rates are high and decrease during exhalation

Units on y axis are : litres per second.


Normal loop (starting from TLC (from VC breath):

  • to A rises rapidly to a flow rate of 8-10Ls-1 at the start of forced expiration)
  • The flow rate then decreases steadily as as expiration continues in a left to right direction, so that a relatively straight line is produced.
  • an important point to demonstrate is the phenomenon of dynamic compression of the airways. The curve traced by the normal loop represents the maximum possible flow rate at each lung volume. Even if patients hold back their maximal effort by expiring slowly at first B they will be unable to cross this maximal flow line. This is because the airways are compressed by a rise in intrathoracic pressure, thus limiting flow. the more effort that is put into expiration the more these airways are compressed and so total flow remains the same.
  • The inspiratory limb has a much squarer shape and a maximum flow rate of 4-6Ls-1, inspiration occurs from RV to TLC in a right to left direction.

Obstructive disease:

  • reduces peak expiratory flow and increases RV (so RV end point shifts to the left - due to gas trapping) + reduced flow rates during all of expiration + increased concavity of expiration line.

Restrictive disease:

  • in contrast markedly reduces TLC (shifts TLC to the right on x axis). PEFR is generally reduced (point A down to 4 flow rate)


Variable intrathoracic obstruction - more likely to allow gas flow during inspiration as the negative intrathoracic pressure generated helps to pull the airways open. (expiratory limb similar to obstructive disease)

Variable extrathoracic obstruction - more likely to allow gas flow during expiration as the positive pressure generated during this phase acts to force the airway open.


Area within loop is smaller in emphysema (resistance increased, TV reduced)

Limitation of inspiratory flow (‘flattened top’) with sub-glottic laryngeal narrowing
question3: What are the lungs other functions (7)
contents3:
• (1) Vascular reservoir
  • underperfused areas of the pulmonary vasculature are ‘recruited’ to accommodate an increase in blood flow and to prevent an increase in pulmonary arterial pressures. 
  • (2) Filter for blood borne matter
  • The lung is ideally positioned to filter out particulate matter such as clots, fibrin clumps, and other endogenous and exogenous materials from entering the systemic circulation.
  • (3) Defence against inhaled particles 
  • Every day, about 10 000 litres of air comes in to contact with 50–100 m2 of alveolar epithelium. There are various mechanisms along the respiratory tract that are involved in providing protection against inhaled physical and chemical substances.
  • (4) Immune function 
  • Optimal lung defences require coordinated action of multiple cell types. Immune function within the lung is mediated by pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAMs) and a variety of immune mediators.
  • (5) Endocrine and metabolic functions
  • Isolated pulmonary neuroendocrine cells (PNECs) and innervated cell clusters called neuroepithelial bodies (NEBs) are widely distributed in the airway mucosa and are together referred to as the ‘pulmonary neuroendocrine system’. 
  • They secrete a wide variety of amines (e.g. serotonin) and peptides (e.g. bombesin). PNEC play a significant role in cell growth, differentiation, and branching morphogenesis in the developing lung. 
  • (6) Pulmonary drug metabolism
  • The lung is an important extra-hepatic site for mixed function oxidation by the cytochrome P450 system but unlike hepatocytes, their activity cannot be induced. 
  • (7) Platelet formation in the lung
  • The abundance of megakaryocytes in the pulmonary circulation coupled with a higher platelet count within the pulmonary vein when compared with the pulmonary artery suggests that megakaryocytes undergo fragmentation within the lungs to produce platelets
contents4:
• Respiratory control
  • patients metabolic rate drops by 15% following induction of anaesthesia
  • Lung mechanics
  • following induction, functional residual capacity FRC falls by 15-20% because there is loss of muscle tone.
  • Gas exchange
  • changes described above can cause atelectasis and inhibit pulmonary vasoconstriction.


Physiology book - How are the lungs affected by GA. 

  • Airway devices : 
  • Manipulation of the airway 
  • Humidification - ETT and LMA’s both bypass the upper airway (incl. Humidification, warming, etc) 
  • Loss of physiological PEEP. 
  • Increase work of breathing - the extent to which airway devices increase the resistance depends on their IR. 
  • Increased dead space. 
  • Lung volumes FRC inevitably reduced due to: 
  • The supine position 
  • The relaxation of the chest wall 
  • Co-morbidities 
  • Patient population 
  • Atelectasis has three causes 
  • Absoption atelectasis - during anaesthesia a combination of diffusable gases and small airway closure 0 due to cC encroaching on teh reduced FRC)
  • Compression atelectassis 
  • Loss of pulmonary surfactant 
  • V/Q relationships 
  • Low lung volument - (due to CC encroaching on FRC) - 
  • Increased tendency for atelectasis 
  • IPPV - which alters intrathoracic pressure, reducing right ventricular preload and changing pulmonary capilliary dynamics - West zone 1 occurs in teh lung apex. 
  • Impairment of HPV by volatile anaesthetics.
